yeah, that's a big win"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:09:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

This doesn't appear to retroactively set this new flag on already create volumes. It seems like that will cause volumes created before this patch to be deleted when we don't want them to?"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:17:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Johannas, the whole problem is that an environment that mixes os-volumes and xensm volumes can't tell the difference.  I don't see anyway to retroactively repair the problem.  Depending on your deployment (in our case ONLY os volumes), a modified version the following script may be a good starting point to help you clean up the current unfortunate situation:

    https://gist.github.com/3311389"}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

As I mentioned in a comment before, we are tagging the VBDs (http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/6.0.0/1.0/en_gb/reference.html#id999215). 
There is no way to store this metadata for an actual volume on the hypervisor in a persistent way. 
So, we tag with every attach and on detach the VBD gets destroyed. This basically means there is no question of retroactively tagging existing volumes, as the VBD created while attaching the volume is the thing that gets tagged.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Also, to be clear, this tags EVERY volume that gets attached via openstack irrespective of the volume driver (iscsi, xensm, etc.). Only disks that got created as a part of the instance creation are not tagged.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:48:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

We need to do *something* since if nothing is done, it looks like horrible things will happen, right?'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-10 17:54:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Johannes, is your concern about the cases where instances *currently* have openstack volumes attached to them?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-10 18:28:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Yes, I'm worried about the case of instances that currently have openstack volumes attached to them. We do for instance. I don't know who else does, but breaking current users is bad."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2012-08-10 18:34:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Johannes:  The problem is that it is already broken, and this patch doesn't add any more brokeness, but at least prevents the issue from happening down the road."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-10 18:42:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

So this nodestroys list was doing absolutely nothing before and was broken?  I'm worried about the removal of that functionality without having set 'osvol' on things."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-10 18:56:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The nodestroys list would work as expected for the xensm driver. 
In case of iscsi volume driver, after the recent fix, n-vol wouldn't crash, but it would not be able to save the attached volume from being destroyed.
This means, if current users try to terminate an instance without first detaching the volumes, the volumes could be destroyed. IOW, the current fix makes it so that in the iscsi driver case, nodestroys makes no difference at all (correct me if I am wrong)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-10 19:01:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

You're right for new instances.

However, let's consider an existing openstack deployment where you have old instances that have volumes attached.  If nodestroys list worked fine with xensm driver before, you would now leave volumes around for those instances?

The pros may outweigh the cons here, but I don't feel like I can +2 this without more information..."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-14 01:28:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I don't know if there are any production deployments using xensm driver, but we could check on the mailing list.

What do you suggest the plan of action should be? We definitely need the tags for the resize bug as well (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1028092)."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I could provide a script that tags all currently attached nova volumes.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-16 20:51:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

A script could be an option. It would be best if it was automatic on startup.

I'd lean towards being conservative and leaking volumes rather than deleting them by accident if some sort of tag hasn't been added.

Not deleting potentially useless data is much safer than deleting potentially important data."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-16 22:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-16 22:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Realistically, the only way we lose untagged volumes after this change is if there was a production deployment of xensm. (so far, I have only heard KTcloudware trying it out).

If there is, the script should fix that problem. I am open to other suggestions too.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-08-16 22:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-16 22:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-08-16 22:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
xenapi: Tag nova volumes during attach_volume

1. Set other_config:'osvol':'True' on VBD during attach.
2. Use this (instead of nodestroys list) to determine which volumes
should not be destroyed on instance terminate.
3. Ensure that the SRs for the attached volumes are forgotten when
instance is terminated.

In the virt/xenapi layer, there is no way to determine which of the
VDIs are nova volumes. This information is required when terminating
and instance, to ensure the volumes are kept intact, as well as other
operations like migrate.

Fixes bug 1030143.

Change-Id: Id1717e64bc29092ce9ffe13b7c254a3867fe8342

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-17 12:44:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If there is an actual problem, such as all backends returning 5xx, this change would ignore the problem.

In the case of account_info(), it would pretend everything was great and cache the account as existing even though it (probably) did not.

In the case of GETorHEAD(), it would return 404 Not Found, even though the cluster is configured for autocreate and so should never return a 404 Not Found for an account.

In the case of POST(), things seem okay since it would return the actual response from the backends."}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2012-08-17 14:09:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> If there is an actual problem, such as all backends
> returning 5xx, this change would ignore the problem.
The self.best_response() in self.make_request() while solve this problem, so this change will not ignore an error.

> In the case of account_info(), it would pretend everything
> was great and cache the account as existing even though it
> (probably) did not.
The account_info() will not cache an account which is not existing. Because, a request to delete a account will marke the account as deleted and delete the account's key in memcached.
Code in swift/proxy/server.py (1891~1893)

> In the case of GETorHEAD(), it would return 404 Not Found, > even though the cluster is configured for autocreate and  > so should never return a 404 Not Found for an account.
This change just return the account-server's response.
HTTP 403 Forbidden
Recently deleted"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-17 14:48:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Okay, good that you've thought on these things. When I get the chance I will test them all out. Are there tests already that verify all these things?"}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2012-08-17 15:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Retuen a reasonable response to client.

As we use the 'account_autocreate' for auto-create accounts, we send a
request to HEAD an account which is just deleted(the account-reaper not
reclaim it immediately), the proxy-server will return 'HTTP 500 Internal
Server Error'.
In my opinion, this is unreasonable, so I change the code in swift/proxy
/server.py for returning a reasonable response. I modified the code in
POST, GETorHEAD and account_info. At last, I modified some code in the
unittest test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Change-Id: Ib057b387c9da073d707ffae49ead54206a8fb7dd
Fixes: Bug #1037889

Is this related to the change that forces me to type my password every time I run a nova command now?"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-09 14:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Doug, the patch to prompt for password in "openstack" cli is already merged as per 9194, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9194/ . The password is prompted if it's not set in env or command line.

This patch, enhances the functionality, to not prompt for password everytime. The password entered by the user is stored in keyring and used during the next time. With this patch, the password is prompted only once, and then on read from keyring.

Please let me know if you need more info and/or want me to tweak the patch.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-09 14:59:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I set my password in the environment variable and nova now prompts me for it every time I run a nova command unless I uninstall the keyring package. Perhaps this is because I don't have a keyring set up?

I want to avoid having the unified CLI introduce the same behavior, so I am trying to understand if this change correctly detects a "the user has no keyring" situation. It should, at the very least, look at the keyring after the shell environment variable in order to maintain backwards compatibility.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-09 15:45:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

To be clear: I do like the idea of using keyring, when it is available. I just want to make sure it doesn't introduce an awkward user experience or backwards-incompatible behavior in the tool that would, for example, make scripting with it more difficult."}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-07-09 15:55:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-10 04:12:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Matt, i fixed the issue you reported with this revised patch.

Doug, the original patch was written to not use keyring, if password is either presented in env or command line. Can you please review the new patch and confirm?

Please note, the change affect only "openstack" cli. It doesn't affect "nova" cli. In other words, the change doesn't impact "nova" cli.'}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-07-10 05:19:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So tested new patch.  Error I encountered before is gone.

Bhuvan:

I see a stack trace if the password I enter is wrong.  We don't want to be showing users stack traces unless they ask for them.  Please print an error.  =D

Doug:

Here is what I am seeing from patch in terms of usability.

If you have an env OS_PASSWORD set... works fine.  No problem.

If you enter the password into keyring... works fine.  One problem.  Not sure it is though.  Seems that once something is in the keyring... it's there.  Like I logged out of my devstack... log back in.  And I can hit admin without entering a password because the keyring is somehow persisting beyond the session.  Not sure that's something we want. Especially on admin.

That's pretty much it.  Otherwise I think this works fine.  

-Matt"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:26:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

How does authentication with the keyring service work? Does the user have to provide some sort of password, or is it assumed that they can get to their keyring because they are logged in already?'}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:30:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

When not in the keyring and without an env for OS_PASSWORD you are prompted to enter a password.  After that the keyring will pass you in.

Not sure on the underlying mechanics.  But it persisting into a whole new session suggests it's probably tying an auth token to a uid.  That's my guess but i have no idea."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:38:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Bhuvan, do you know how the keychain persistence works?'}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-07-10 22:05:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

http://pypi.python.org/pypi/keyring/

Looks like its a pass through to the user's default keyring service. In ubuntu I believe that's gnome-keyring.

So same way you load up keys most likely to commit code ( if you are using ubuntu for that ).

-Matt"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-10 22:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Doug: Adding to Matt's summary, Keyring is a regular password management service. Python keyring supports gnome-keyring, kde-keyring, osx-keyring, depending on the OS. We may use applications like seahorse, kwallet to manage credentials.

That said, it doesn't maintain user session. It's just a convenient way to manage password, than specifying in environment variable or command line.

Matt, I'd believe the traceback error is not a regression caused by this patch. It seem to occur if we enter wrong password in the prompt, or env['OS_PASSWORD'] or command line. Please confirm. Do, "-1" if it's a regression. I'll investigate.'}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-07-10 22:35:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That may be true.  I'll enter a bug for it for now then and we can just patch update it later."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-11 16:05:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

With the patch and OS_PASSWORD set, I get the expected behavior (no prompt):

vagrant@vagrant-precise:/opt/stack/python-openstackclient$ openstack list user
+----------------------------------+--------+
| ID                               | Name   |
+----------------------------------+--------+
| 01b7d16276994aa4870e171e4455843a | nova   |
| 82d6692303284a0ab5f187111a6f8885 | admin  |
| d75a560de2244315bf2fa41e9d01a7bd | glance |
| ed9eebe2a8b045e89052d83068ace239 | demo   |
+----------------------------------+--------+

Without OS_PASSWORD set I am asked first for the openstack password and then for a new password for my keyring. That all makes sense:

$ unset OS_PASSWORD
$ openstack list user
Password: 
Please set a password for your new keyring
Password (again): 
Please input your password for the keyring
+----------------------------------+--------+
| ID                               | Name   |
+----------------------------------+--------+
| 01b7d16276994aa4870e171e4455843a | nova   |
| 82d6692303284a0ab5f187111a6f8885 | admin  |
| d75a560de2244315bf2fa41e9d01a7bd | glance |
| ed9eebe2a8b045e89052d83068ace239 | demo   |
+----------------------------------+--------+

And every time I run the client I am asked for the keyring password:

$ openstack list user
Please input your password for the keyring

My guess is I see this because I am accessing this server remotely, and therefore don't have any of the gnome or KDE services that would cache the keyring authentication. That's no worse than prompting me for the keystone password every time, I guess. Setting OS_PASSWORD again does seem to bypass the keyring check.

Before we put this change in, I would like to see it updated to gracefully handle not having the keyring package installed. Not every environment is going to want to have keyring set up, so I don't think we should make it a hard requirement for installing the CLI.

I think we would also benefit from a blueprint and/or mailing list discussion describing the motivation and how the common CLI use cases (interactive local, interactive remote, script with multiple commands run interactively, non-interactive command such as a cron job), are impacted by the change."}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-12 03:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Doug, Thank you for detailed review comments. Please find attached revised patch, to handle keyring. With this patch, if keyring python library is not installed, the original behavior is preserved.'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-12 03:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-12 03:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

How many times do they have to enter their keyring password?"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-18 00:12:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Doug,
Documented the keyring support as it is today (after this patch) in here:
http://wiki.openstack.org/KeyringSupport

Can you please review it? Once you confirm, i'll send a note to openstack@lists.launchpad.net forum. Let me know if we should also track it in a bug. If yes, i'll open a bug and link this patch to that bug.

In the meantime, i'll incorporate your (inline) review comment."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-25 15:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sorry for the long delay in replying, I was traveling last week.

The wiki page looks like a good start for documentation, but I think the folks writing the user manual are going to want some more details.

For example, it isn't clear to me how I can configure the keyring access code to not prompt me for a password for the keyring itself every time I run the client without using Gnome or KDE (those won't be available when I ssh into a remote server). I know I can bypass the keyring check entirely by using one of the other mechanisms for setting the openstack client password (the command line option or the environment variable), but that defeats the purpose of having the keyring in the first place, right? Is it possible to have the keyring access prompt once per "login" or something, or is the keyring really only usable like that for desktop users?

I wanted to move this conversation to the mailing list because I would like to get feedback from other people (about the implementation and about the desirability of the feature) and because communicating long messages through comments on the patch is cumbersome.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-25 15:10:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

See also the doc change in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9783/ This patch should update the README to explain the change in flow triggered by the keyring library.'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-29 05:24:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Doug, thank you for detailed comment, once again.

After thinking about it for a while, I tweaked the patch to store using UncryptedFileKeyring backend. With this patch, the password for keyring is not prompted. The behavior is same across all systems, be it with desktop or no. The password is stored in ~/.openstack-keyring.cfg file. Every time, the password is read from this file.

I'll post revised patch for README.rst, once 9783 goes in.

I'll also tweak the twiki document http://wiki.openstack.org/KeyringSupport in line with this patch and post a note to mailing list."}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-07-29 05:24:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-29 05:26:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

So now there is an option to control the setting, but no environment variable? I thought we wanted both.'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-08-07 22:57:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Doug, as per your recommendation, we have it as a boolean argument. Using env('OS_USE_KEYRING') sounds like a over-design for this little feature.

The feature had evolved from nowhere, to store encrypted password in keyring. In the beginning, we intent to use environment variable. As it evolved, a simple (boolean) argument is suffice to enable/disable this feature. I believe, we don't need environment variable."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-08-08 13:08:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

IMO I think the env variable is useful. I was just doing some work on a devstack vm (i.e: keyring would use text file encrypted keyring) and when working with novaclient which has the keyring support I would need to specify the option --no_cache all the time or it would bugs me asking me for my encrypted text password :

stack@devstack:~$ nova list
Please input your password for the keyring

this is deeply annoying on a dev box (i.e: password is password on that vm) and I was about to log  a bug report for novaclient when I saw this.

Just my 2c :)"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-08-08 14:28:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-08 14:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-openstackclient-python27/91/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-08-08 14:34:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Doug, Chmouel: tweaked the patch to use both command line option --os-use-keyring and env(OS_USE_KEYRING).'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-08-09 15:17:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-08-09 16:28:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Doug, env doesn't convert '0' to False. That's why we check for following condition:

        if self.options.os_use_keyring is True or \
           self.options.os_use_keyring == 'True':"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-08-09 20:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: (3 inline comments)

  OpenStackClient.authenticate_user(): Get password from keyring,

  get password from keyring.

  password in keyring.

  Define keyring as one of dependent.

  The abstract class for keyring, specifically for openstack. The

  OpenStackClient.authenticate_user(): Get password from keyring,
  if it is defined; otherwise, prompt for the password. If user
  enter a password and keyring is enabled, store it in keyring.

  is enabled, with OS_USE_KEYRING environment variable.

  openstack backend for keyring.
  OpenStackClient.get_password_from_keyring(): New method to
  get password from keyring.
  OpenStackClient.set_password_in_keyring(): New method go set

  Define keyring and pycrypto as one of dependent.

commit_message:
Keyring support for openstackclient.

Bug: 1030440

If password is defined in keyring, use it; otherwise, prompt for the
password. Keying is configured using command line switch,
--os-use-keyring or env(OS_USE_KEYRING).

* openstackclient/common/openstackkeyring.py
  The abstract class for keyring, specifically for openstack. The
  class is used to store encrypted password in keyring, without
  prompting for keyring password. The encrypted password is
  stored in ~/.openstack-keyring.cfg file.

* openstack-common.py
  Update openstackkeyring library from openstack.common.

* openstackclient/shell.py
  OpenStackClient.build_option_parser(): New boolean argument,
   --os-use-keyring, default to env(OS_USE_KEYRING).
  OpenStackClient.authenticate_user(): Get password from keyring,
  if it is defined; otherwise, prompt for the password. If user
  enter a password and keyring is enabled, store it in keyring.
  OpenStackClient.init_keyring_backend(): New method to define
  openstack backend for keyring.
  OpenStackClient.get_password_from_keyring(): New method to
  get password from keyring.
  OpenStackClient.set_password_in_keyring(): New method go set
  password in keyring.

* toos/pip-requires
  Define keyring and pycrypto as one of dependent.

Change-Id: I36d3a63054658c0ef0553d68b38fefbc236930ef

commit_message:
Fix hacking.py git checks to propagate errors

Now when N801 or N802 is hit tools/hacking.py will return -1.

Fix bug 1039697

Change-Id: I9f6950a4396ae82861e5de0e4f3ba8b482c4fdf8

commit_message:
Update docs for new ring serialization.

The Admin Guide now contains information about the ring serialization
change (and importantly, how to downgrade, if necessary).

Also added container-server conf var, "allow_versions" to the Deployment
Guide.

Also changed description of proxy-server conf var,
"max_containers_whitelist" to say it contains "account names" not
"account hashes".

Change-Id: Ib23c6118cc5195cc04765afd28e442e4c735f0d4

commit_message:
Validate the nose test case wrapper test member.

Apparently not every nose test case wrapper has a test member. Validate
that the member exists before accessing it. If the test case does not
have a test member check if it is a Test Suite with a _tests member.
Iterate over that iterable of tests if it exists.

Change-Id: Ie1afeb3ebc023f114975a84d8757d0c282932834

commit_message:
Linuxbridge support for L3 agent

Fixes bug 1037245

For the linux bridge this changes the generic interface name prefix
from "dhc" to "ns-".

Change-Id: I37078dadcbffa7e0b45d1523e7a03bb7c0d36919

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-07-11 22:31:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(16 inline comments)

Hi! Welcome to your first OpenStack code review! :)

Clearly this patch is just a starting point -- I see that some of the driver stuff is just really mock/stubbed out and not complete. Therefore, I will in this first review just focus on some things in the code that will need to be addressed before going forward. See inline comments, but in general, here are the issues you will need to address:

a) Please read the style guidelines for Nova code in the HACKING document and adhere to these guidelines. I've given you some guidance inline on much of the HACKING rules, but have not marked every single place where mistakes are made. You can run the tools/hacking.py script against your code to find them all.

b) Exceptions will need to be handled properly. Right now, you have a lot of print exception stuff which will clearly need to be re-done to log an exception and properly re-raise the exception to a higher level.

c) Make sure that all classes have docstrings that clearly indicate their purpose unless the purpose is obvious.

d) In /nova/virt/powervm/__init__.py it would be useful for you to add some detailed documentation -- including links to online resources -- for how the PowerVM virt driver is structured.

All the best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 4601, 'date': '2012-07-16 19:54:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-16 20:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Tiago"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-22 17:05:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-21 17:27:25.000000000', 'message': 'Adds missing assertion to FloatingIP tests

Adding assertions to some tests to ensure that we catch the
return status_int. Found that test_floating_ip_disassociate would
actually fail the test if status_int was caught. Adding the
get_instance_by_floating_ip_addr stub to to the disassociate test
to ensure that the test is proper. Fixes bug 1039432.

Also making a minor change in test_bad_param_in_remove_floating_ip
which should call _remove_floating_ip rather than _add_floating_ip.

Change-Id: Id43f785bb0e6b7405e2d292292c4126d7ed656cb
'}, {'created': '2012-08-22 14:12:27.000000000', 'message': 'Adds missing assertion to FloatingIP tests

Adding assertions to some tests to ensure that we catch the
return status_int. Found that test_floating_ip_disassociate would
actually fail the test if status_int was caught. Adding the
get_instance_by_floating_ip_addr stub to to the disassociate test
to return the test instance on IP match. This is required because
get_instance_by_floating_ip_addr is stubbed in setup to return None.
Fixes bug 1039432.

Also making a minor change in test_bad_param_in_remove_floating_ip
which should call _remove_floating_ip rather than _add_floating_ip.

Change-Id: Id43f785bb0e6b7405e2d292292c4126d7ed656cb
'}]
commit_message:
Adds missing assertion to FloatingIP tests

Adding assertions to some tests to ensure that we catch the
return status_int. Found that test_floating_ip_disassociate would
actually fail the test if status_int was caught. Adding the
get_instance_by_floating_ip_addr stub to to the disassociate test
to return the test instance on IP match. This is required because
get_instance_by_floating_ip_addr is stubbed in setup to return None.
Fixes bug 1039432.

Also making a minor change in test_bad_param_in_remove_floating_ip
which should call _remove_floating_ip rather than _add_floating_ip.

Change-Id: Id43f785bb0e6b7405e2d292292c4126d7ed656cb

Two minor nits:

Instead of LOG.info I would do LOG.warning as this is a potential error situation.

Anyway, how can we end up in this situation? Is it just an exceptional condition, or is there probably some cleanup needed?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-22 15:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Hi,
The problem is usually a case of running devstack's ./stack.sh, ./unstack.sh and then ./stack.sh again.
It is an edge case.
I'll update the error message.
In addition to this I plan to address the cleanup with devstack (hopefully soon)
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-22 15:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-22 15:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

While this exception treatment clearly avoids a crash in run_{ovs|of}ctl, I think there's a good chance we will still end up with an agent crash at some other point in the code; for instance in the case of db_get_map it seems there will be a crash because a NoneType was expected in place of an Iterable.

Unfortunately I am not sure which is the right way forward; I think we have the following options:
1) re-raise after an error in ovs commands, and let the agent die. 
2) retry the commands until they succeed (removing --timeout)
3) something in the middle between (1) and (2)
4) have ovs commands return empty output but in the format the caller would expect in case of failures (e.g.: an empty list instead of None).

Please note: If I got all wrong, it is because it's monday morning, so I'm excused :)"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Did not spot you already fixed this.
this is good enough for me at the moment.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thanks Gary. All comments review comments are addressed.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Hi,
Thanks for the comments. This is indeed a tough one. I managed to reproduce the initial problem and after the fixes in the above patch I did not see any other exceptions. I hope that this may suffice, but you do have some valid points.
My mantra is that the agents should be up 24/7.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Gary
Thank you for your fixing this.
Any utils.execute call could fail, so another utils.execute call should be handled.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-22 14:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

[{'created': '2012-08-22 11:14:38.000000000', 'message': 'enable router deletion logic in l3-agent

bug 1039387

related to bp quantum-l3-fwd-nat

previous diff logic did not attempt to detect that a router was deleted.

Also, enabled actual deletion of namespace, since 066e48be08f155c29887f5846902fbf5e41b8c89 fixed the issue that was causing that to break.

Also, make router loop pay attention to admin_state_up on router ports.

Change-Id: Id76736dd3207472dfc282097e5b27740e05aaa3a
'}, {'created': '2012-08-22 11:14:38.000000000', 'message': 'enable router deletion logic in l3-agent

bug 1039387

related to bp quantum-l3-fwd-nat

previous diff logic did not attempt to detect that a router was deleted.

Also, enabled actual deletion of namespace, since 066e48be08f155c29887f5846902fbf5e41b8c89 fixed the issue that was causing that to break.

Also, make router loop pay attention to admin_state_up on router ports.

Change-Id: Id76736dd3207472dfc282097e5b27740e05aaa3a
'}]
commit_message:
enable router deletion logic in l3-agent

bug 1039387

related to bp quantum-l3-fwd-nat

previous diff logic did not attempt to detect that a router was deleted.

Also, enabled actual deletion of namespace, since 066e48be08f155c29887f5846902fbf5e41b8c89 fixed the issue that was causing that to break.

Also, make router loop pay attention to admin_state_up on router ports.

Change-Id: Id76736dd3207472dfc282097e5b27740e05aaa3a

commit_message:
Add nosehtmloutput as a test dependency.

Adding nosehtmloutput as a test dependency allows nose to output its
results to an html file. This will be used by Jenkins to save logs on
a different server.

Change-Id: If88ca04bf7e45aa25aaea3cc01bb0f457224c117

commit_message:
Introduce ImagePropertiesFilter scheduler filter

Commit d39137fa added functionality to the ComputeFilter to filter on
architecture, hypervisor_type, and vm_mode. The existing ArchFilter
already filtered on architecture. This patch merges the ComputeFilter
functionality introduced in d39137fa with the ArchFilter to create the
ImagePropertiesFilter.  The ImagePropertiesFilter uses image properties
specified in the request_spec to filter hosts.

This patch also adds the ImagePropertiesFilter to the list of default
filters specified by the scheduler_default_filters FLAG.

Fixes LP Bug #1037339

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ifa6fccf2db266b0fe3457d58fc81fdb50ffcbc0f

commit_message:
v3 Policy & Catalog

- v3 catalog tests (bug 1023933)
- v3 catalog implementation (bug 1023938)
- v3 policy (bp rbac-keystone-api)
- v3 policy tests (bug 1023935)
- v3 policy implementation (bug 1023939)

Overview:
- Added v3 sample conf, routers, controllers
- Policy KVS & SQL backends both extend the rules backend
- Injecting managers into v3 controllers to avoid circular dependencies
- New client tests are dependent on corresponding client changes:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9237/

Change-Id: I97c5a2f7a84e3fca0adaea020697f958e04f5753

messages:

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I think adding shared to the attribute map with allow_post and allow_put both set to false should not make any harm.

I will also fix the update and add a test case for it.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Please note that at the moment we are implicitly assuming all subnets on a shared network are shared too.
I am using a new attribute in the model instead of performing a join as I though it was more efficient.

This is because the default policy allows admins only for creating subnets on shared networks.

Moving to a place where the 'shared' attribute is configurable for subnets too would not require a huge diff. Just some changes to db_base_plugin and policy.json"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Thanks for the patch.

I confirmed this patch works in my devstack env. Tenant 'invisible_to_admin' succeeded port-create for public network.

I agree that at the moment 'shared' attribute of subnet does not need to be configurable."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi,
I have a few comments:
1. I think that the 'shared' field should appear in the attributes table for the subnet. The allow_put and allow_post should be set as False. I think that this will make it a little bit safer. I am not sure if you want to check the subnet update to ensure that the 'shared' value is the same as that as the network
2. Following Akihiro's comments I also think that a test case for the network 'shared' update should be added.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-22 05:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for addressing the issues. Works for me.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-21 22:02:01.000000000', 'message': 'A couple minor tweaks to the SAIO guide.

Added "-p" to mkdir cmds in a "set -e" script (/etc/rc.local).

/var/log/swift gets owned by the group "adm", but isn't group writeable
by default, so the find/rm in "resetswift" fails.  So I added a chmod to
add group-write for that directory tree.

Added commands for installing tox.

Change-Id: Ic141491272a83a9233cd6a6a70c3ef74411f3f51
'}, {'created': '2012-08-21 23:18:53.000000000', 'message': 'A couple minor tweaks to the SAIO guide.

Added "-p" to mkdir cmds in a "set -e" script (/etc/rc.local).

/var/log/swift gets owned by the group "adm", but isn't group writeable
by default, so the find/rm in "resetswift" fails.  So I added a chmod to
add group-write for that directory tree.

Added commands for installing tox.

Change-Id: Ic141491272a83a9233cd6a6a70c3ef74411f3f51
'}]
commit_message:
A couple minor tweaks to the SAIO guide.

Added "-p" to mkdir cmds in a "set -e" script (/etc/rc.local).

/var/log/swift gets owned by the group "adm", but isn't group writeable
by default, so the find/rm in "resetswift" fails.  So I added a chmod to
add group-write for that directory tree.

Added commands for installing tox.

Change-Id: Ic141491272a83a9233cd6a6a70c3ef74411f3f51

commit_message:
A few misc. code cleanups.

Fixed a couple config gets which weren't using TRUE_VALUES (hopefully
the last ones?).

Removed a deprecated parameter from
swift.common.db.ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter() a "TODO" which dates
back to the original import of Swift into github.

Also made AccountBroker.reclaim()'s docstring match its arg names.

Change-Id: I646bdd00a3693763b55a50ba210c7ed2ba1df4cd

Jim, Thanks for your comment. I will put more detailed commit message.

Vish, There was a discussion on no-keyword case. Originally, Mark's way was the behavior, and I wanted to maintain it with 8089 merge. However, another patch (trusted filter, I think) accepted already use the extra_spec and no-keyword case was used for that. So, we opened the issue to mailing list, and there was no objection to go that way, i.e., if there is no keyword, it will be ignored. That is why I had to modify my proposal again to follow the community preference... If the original way is used, the trusted filter will be broken."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-20 18:17:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

'}, {'created': '2012-08-20 18:37:05.000000000', 'message': 'Debugged extra_specs_ops.py

The current extra_specs_ops.py under nova/scheduler/filters has two bugs
that are debugged with this patch:
    - Extra_specs with no keyword is not ignored. If a keyword such as
      "=" and ">=" is not given in extra_specs, the extra_specs must be ignored.
    - Crahses if <in> is not followed by a word. For example, if
      "<in> gpu <in>" is given in extra_specs, current code tries to pop a word
      after the second <in> that causes a crash. This patch let it ignore the
      "<in>" keyword if no word follows the second "<in>" keyword.

Debugged bug 1038979

Change-Id: I80a6eafd7ee57a2f3ccbf2fb869655ab84e92cf2
'}, {'created': '2012-08-20 23:27:02.000000000', 'message': 'Debugged extra_specs_ops.py

The current extra_specs_ops.py under nova/scheduler/filters has a bug:
it crahses if <in> is not followed by a word. For example, if
"<in> gpu <in>" is given in extra_specs, current code tries to pop a
word after the second <in> that causes a crash. This patch lets it
ignore the "<in>" keyword if no word follows the second "<in>" keyword.

Debugged bug 1038979

Change-Id: I80a6eafd7ee57a2f3ccbf2fb869655ab84e92cf2
'}, {'created': '2012-08-21 10:57:15.000000000', 'message': 'Debugged extra_specs_ops.py

The current extra_specs_ops.py under nova/scheduler/filters has a bug:
it crahses if <or> is not followed by a word. For example, if
"<or> gpu <or>" is given in extra_specs, current code tries to pop a
word after the second <or> that causes a crash. This patch lets it
ignore the "<or>" keyword if no word follows the second "<or>" keyword.

Debugged bug 1038979

Change-Id: I80a6eafd7ee57a2f3ccbf2fb869655ab84e92cf2
'}, {'created': '2012-08-21 11:35:46.000000000', 'message': 'Debugged extra_specs_ops.py

The current extra_specs_ops.py under nova/scheduler/filters has a bug:
it crahses if <or> is not followed by a word. For example, if
"<or> gpu <or>" is given in extra_specs, current code tries to pop a
word after the second <or> that causes a crash. This patch lets it
ignore the "<or>" keyword if no word follows the second "<or>" keyword.

Debugged bug 1038979

Change-Id: I80a6eafd7ee57a2f3ccbf2fb869655ab84e92cf2
'}]
commit_message:
Debugged extra_specs_ops.py

The current extra_specs_ops.py under nova/scheduler/filters has a bug:
it crahses if <or> is not followed by a word. For example, if
"<or> gpu <or>" is given in extra_specs, current code tries to pop a
word after the second <or> that causes a crash. This patch lets it
ignore the "<or>" keyword if no word follows the second "<or>" keyword.

Debugged bug 1038979

Change-Id: I80a6eafd7ee57a2f3ccbf2fb869655ab84e92cf2

Seems sensible enough, but it seems like we should (a) give this warning for people who try and use it for compute scheduling and (b) give a general deprecation warning if people use nova-volumes and avoid also showing this warning'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-08-21 03:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joe: I think this is a go (I've looked at it several times).

Do you have any thoughts on Markmc's reply (about logging this  messages only for compute scheduling stuff and a separate generic message for volumes?). The deprecated.warn function can be safely moved into one of the scheduler methods that gets called multiple times... it should only log the message on the first try. If you do that I think everyone is happy here :)"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-08-21 17:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-08-21 18:00:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Have compute_node_get() join 'service'

Fixes bug 1039633

compute_node_get() is used by hypervisors extension and it accesses
compute_node['service'].  Lazy joins fail now and then..

Also fixes line continuation indents with other compute_node calls in
sqlalchemy/api.py

Change-Id: I3ac02aad739e96a4866a64cabe859cf484341784

subject: Adds starting point for an OpenStack CLI guide.
messages:
[{'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-08-13 15:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-13 18:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-08-13 18:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

One comment inline.

How should we review this? 

Is this a WIP, should we be reviewing for content, or is the plan to get this in first and then focus on content?'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:51:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This book now fails to build: api-quick-start. 

I have sent other (editorial) comments for cli-guide in an email and will copy them here shortly."}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Here are my comments - also sent by email:

**Overview** 

You're missing an overview for the book - tell what the book is about and why someone would want to use it.
 
*Install OpenStack CLIs (glance, keystone, nova, swift, quantum)*

(rewrite) Each OpenStack project has a command-line-interface (CLI) that interacts with the REST API for the service. A common openstack client is in development also.

The clients [what clients? you only mention CLIs so far...] are open-source Python clients used to run commands to make API calls. Each nova client command runs cURL commands that embed API v2 requests. You can run the nova client from a desktop machine or remote system. For example, to use the Compute API from the command-line, install the nova client. 

**general note – this introduction is not clear – you only tell how to install the nova client, but you talk about other clients here. Revise the introduction to make it clear that there are multiple clients. Explain briefly what each client does, and why type of commands are available.** 

Procedure 1. To install the nova client:

Revise the install procedure to make "nova" a variable that people use to substitute the correct client name. This isn't clear right now. Better still, provide a separate chapter for each client with an install procedure and a list of commands in a readable format, plus an example of using the client commands to do one or more tasks.



 *Command List for glance CLI*

(and other command lists)

Just recommend that they run glance help or nova help to get the latest command list. These change so it's best to let them discover these commands. If you want to include the command lists, put them in a more readable format than just the output from the help commands.

 *Create Your Server with the nova Client*

Does openstack use the same flavor and image Ids? I use an actual flavor and image ID in my examples. Also, before you can run this command to create a server, you must run nova credentials and nova endpoints, and also nova image-list and nova flavor-list. This one command is insufficient.

**Suggested re-org**

1. Overview - what the book is about, why someone would want to use it. Describe each client and its uses. Mention that installation procedure is similar for each client. Mention that you can get help for commands by typing <client_name> help or <client_name> help <command_name> for a specific command.


2. Authentication - describe authentication and endpoints.

3. glance client
   3a. Install the glance client
   3b. glance client command list
   3c. glance client example
4. keystone client
   4a. Install the keystone client
   4b. keystone client command list
   4c. keystone client example
5. nova client
   5a. etc etc'}, {'account_id': 1177, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Anne,
As Diane suggested lets keep client along with the component. This will help in better organized content and easy/understandable approach.'}, {'account_id': 1177, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

1. glance 
   1a. Introduction 
   1b. Installing glance
       1b1. Ubuntu
       1b2. Redhat
       1b3. Source
 
    1c.Install the glance client
       1c1. Ubuntu
       1c2. Redhat
       1c3. Source
   1d. glance command list
   1e. glance example

This is how i see it, just provided glance as example.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-14 20:35:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-08-15 16:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the changes and the direction. A few comments:
- Still missing an overview
- Inconsistent use of verb forms in titles. Sometimes it's simple form, like "Install," and then it's gerund form like, "Listing," or "Showing." Make all simple form - Install, List, Check, Launch, etc. Don't use gerunds.
- Organization needs some tweaking - 

A. OpenStack Nova CLI
   a. Install
   b. Command List
   c. Do this command
   d. Do that command
B. OpenStack Glance CLI
   a. Install
   b. Command List
C. OpenStack Quantum CLI
   a. Install
   b. Command List


- Finally, you can move the "getting help" topic above all the individual CLI sections - and make it generic. I think you get help for CLI commands in the same way no matter what the CLI. 

nova help

nova help list

nova help credentials

(etc)

or glance help

glance image-create help


(etc)

so <cli> help for general help

or <cli> help <command> for specific help for a command'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:14:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks reviewers - I'd like to get this published so we can keep working on it even though it's not perfect. Agreed? Vote if you think it's okay to publish in this form."}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:39:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-08-20 22:35:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Just one comment about the user tag <literallayout> instead of program listing. Fantastic work Anne though :)'}, {'account_id': 1177, 'date': '2012-08-21 03:09:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Looks good to me Anne.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-08-21 04:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Lovely start :)'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-08-21 23:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-21 23:14:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-manuals-merge/701/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-21 23:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-13 14:33:42.000000000', 'message': 'Adds starting point for an OpenStack CLI guide.

Only has nova client commands for now.
Need to add swift, glance, and keystone.
Also need to add an overview that there will be an openstack

commit_message:
Adds starting point for an OpenStack CLI guide.

Patchset reorganizes based on feedback.

Patchset 4 and 5 addresses Diane's feedback, separating out version, help,
and so on.
Patchset 6 renames some files, adds some glance CLI commands in an
outline, unfinished.

Fixes
bug 1019718
bug 1031578
bug 988902

Change-Id: I530b29eca200830d866b09431e522efdc3454f2c

commit_message:
Fixed bug where expirer would get confused by...

Fixed bug where expirer would get confused by odd deletion times.
Since this has already rolled out, I just capped things at ten 9s, or
Sat Nov 20 17:46:39 2286. I can't wait for the Y2286 world panic. :/

Change-Id: Iba10963faa344a418a1fa573d5c85f4ff864b574

commit_message:
Add policy check for downloading image.

This patch adds a policy, 'download_image', to be enforced when image data is
retrieved. It also does some basic refactoring of how policies are enforced.

Fixes bug 1038086

Change-Id: Idd844b615d362eae3197e106067c29dba8e3eeda

commit_message:
Update command descriptions

Several commands did not have descriptions or the descriptions
they had were insufficient. This adds mission descriptions
and fattens up those that were too lean.

Change-Id: I091ae70cdae5d3f72f273519d88873cb5392ba3b

commit_message:
Simplify docs and provide 'News' on index.rst

* The index page is now a set of release notes and a quickstart guide
* Shrink the README (pypi doc page) and move it into the doc site
* Drop the link to the autoindex module docs

Change-Id: I276b1228ba4006279c112eb487dcde9e45c4f344

commit_message:
Add nosehtmloutput as a test dependency.

Adding nosehtmloutput as a test dependency allows nose to output its
results to an html file. This will be used by Jenkins to save logs on
a different server.

Change-Id: Id194f3e40b0964f24bbd286d8c996f43c8dfae08

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-20 16:08:29.000000000', 'message': "Add back necessary import.

Unit tests are failing because an import of glance/common/config.py was removed.
When it is imported it registers a few common cfg opts that otherwise would not
be registered. If this doesn't happen then unittests will fail since they expect
those opts.

Change-Id: Ib90c0af3d935243fd0aa8487131305f6843c1330
"}]
commit_message:
Add back necessary import.

Unit tests are failing because an import of glance/common/config.py was removed.
When it is imported it registers a few common cfg opts that otherwise would not
be registered. If this doesn't happen then unittests will fail since they expect
those opts.

Change-Id: Ib90c0af3d935243fd0aa8487131305f6843c1330

commit_message:
Updated probe tests

The probe tests were woefully out of date with all the changes that
have ocurred since they were written. I've updated most of them and
removed some that are hopeless outdated.

I also greatly improved the timing issues (hopefully completely
solved them? I ran them 25 times with no problems) and made them pep8
1.3.1 safe.

Change-Id: I8e9dbb6e7d6e04e293843b1dce1ded99d84e0348

commit_message:
Add tests for PAM authentication.

Bug: 1003829

* keystone/config.py
  Define defaults for pam.

* tests/backend_pam.conf
  Defaults to execute pam tests.

* tests/test_backend_pam.py
  New script to test all implemented methods for pam backend.

Change-Id: I891f080c36fbdc1d641d49edf9fe762702b591b6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-21 18:34:10.000000000', 'message': "Make glance image service check base exception classes

Fixes bug 1039675

glanceclient can raise HTTPNotFound (as well as NotFound) it appears,
but glance image service is only converting NotFound ->
InstanceNotFound.  Same applies to 'Forbidden' and other exceptions.

This patch converts 'exc_type is NotFound'-like checks to use
'isinstance' instead, which will cover HTTPNotFound, etc.

Change-Id: I0982875e667121cee3da3cfe0124499cad484fa6
"}]
commit_message:
Make glance image service check base exception classes

Fixes bug 1039675

glanceclient can raise HTTPNotFound (as well as NotFound) it appears,
but glance image service is only converting NotFound ->
InstanceNotFound.  Same applies to 'Forbidden' and other exceptions.

This patch converts 'exc_type is NotFound'-like checks to use
'isinstance' instead, which will cover HTTPNotFound, etc.

Change-Id: I0982875e667121cee3da3cfe0124499cad484fa6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-21 01:34:14.000000000', 'message': "Convert limiting_iter to LimitingReader.

Glance commit 3c69df5aa707b4216ef7001dbe28fa0a5912493c added a new
limiting_iter function in utils which we use to limit reads to
image data being uploaded. This simple generator doesn't work
with image backends like the Swift store which require a 'read'
method.

This patch swaps out the simple limiting_iter function for a
LimitingReader class which supports both 'read' and __iter__
functions.

Fixes LP Bug #1039212 which cause the exception below when used
with the previous code:

Change-Id: I87d9a30f7afe0207386d621050312374ced161d5
AttributeError: 'CooperativeReader' object has no attribute 'read'
"}, {'created': '2012-08-21 01:37:38.000000000', 'message': "Convert limiting_iter to LimitingReader.

Glance commit 3c69df5aa707b4216ef7001dbe28fa0a5912493c added a new
limiting_iter function in utils which we use to limit reads to
image data being uploaded. This simple generator doesn't work
with image backends like the Swift store which require a 'read'
method.

This patch swaps out the simple limiting_iter function for a
LimitingReader class which supports both 'read' and __iter__
functions.

Fixes LP Bug #1039212 which cause the exception below when used
with the previous code:

AttributeError: 'CooperativeReader' object has no attribute 'read'

Change-Id: I87d9a30f7afe0207386d621050312374ced161d5
"}, {'created': '2012-08-21 16:34:26.000000000', 'message': "Convert limiting_iter to LimitingReader.

Glance commit 3c69df5aa707b4216ef7001dbe28fa0a5912493c added a new
limiting_iter function in utils which we use to limit reads to
image data being uploaded. This simple generator doesn't work
with image backends like the Swift store which require a 'read'
method.

This patch swaps out the simple limiting_iter function for a
LimitingReader class which supports both 'read' and __iter__
functions.

Fixes LP Bug #1039212 which cause the exception below when used
with the previous code:

AttributeError: 'CooperativeReader' object has no attribute 'read'

Change-Id: I87d9a30f7afe0207386d621050312374ced161d5
"}]
commit_message:
Convert limiting_iter to LimitingReader.

Glance commit 3c69df5aa707b4216ef7001dbe28fa0a5912493c added a new
limiting_iter function in utils which we use to limit reads to
image data being uploaded. This simple generator doesn't work
with image backends like the Swift store which require a 'read'
method.

This patch swaps out the simple limiting_iter function for a
LimitingReader class which supports both 'read' and __iter__
functions.

Fixes LP Bug #1039212 which cause the exception below when used
with the previous code:

AttributeError: 'CooperativeReader' object has no attribute 'read'

Change-Id: I87d9a30f7afe0207386d621050312374ced161d5

The explanation that system metadata is treated the way it is because it isn't yet being joined in normally during instance_get calls made a lot of sense to me. I could easily see us fixing that in order to support an extension that exposes system metadata. So I could also see going back to the approach in patchset 1 (just making sure we get the new metadata and not the old in the notification).

commit_message:
Implements sending notification on metadata change

It would be good to have a notification sent every time there is change
in the metadata. This merge prop implements sending a
compute.instance.update event for the above change.

fixes bug 1034547

Change-Id: I451796b6a83c4782df6f72f083755527ebd62a52

commit_message:
Enable DHCP agent to work with plugin when L2 agents use DB polling

Fixes bug 1039393

By default the plugins will enable the RPC support. If and only if
the agent RPC is enabled will RPC notification messages be sent to the
agents

Change-Id: I4fb003a2b477e5e647c3ee408b449e71b3f5a883

commit_message:
Support the possibility of using entry-points.

If console scripts are generated via entry-points, they will go into
/usr/local/bin on python setup.py develop and they will not be found in
/opt/stack/$PROJECT/bin any more. This patch supports a transition to
entry-points console scripts, but should still allow the old thing too.

Change-Id: I816f5f796ad00ac55a8352743ba01723df140072

Then include a pointer to that in the CHANGELOG."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-16 01:43:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2012-08-15 09:45:03.000000000', 'message': 'Make old pickle format the default.

To improve forward-compatibility (old Swift versions being able to read
rings serialized by new Swift verisons), rings continue to be serialized
with Python pickle by default.

The new format (much more efficiently deserialized than pickled rings
written by Python 2.7) may be selected by passing a "version=1" kwarg to
swift.common.ring.ring.RingData.save() or by including an optional
trailing argument of "1" to swift-ring-builder's "rebalance" and
"write_ring" commands.  In both cases, the argument itself is optional
and defaults to version 0 (pickling).

The new code continues to be able to load rings serialized in either
format.

Change-Id: Ia575beca8885317480a8a7753d9cb32758aa22c6
'}]
commit_message:
Make old pickle format the default.

To improve forward-compatibility (old Swift versions being able to read
rings serialized by new Swift verisons), rings continue to be serialized
with Python pickle by default.

The new format (much more efficiently deserialized than pickled rings
written by Python 2.7) may be selected by passing a "version=1" kwarg to
swift.common.ring.ring.RingData.save() or by including an optional
trailing argument of "1" to swift-ring-builder's "rebalance" and
"write_ring" commands.  In both cases, the argument itself is optional
and defaults to version 0 (pickling).

The new code continues to be able to load rings serialized in either
format.

Change-Id: Ia575beca8885317480a8a7753d9cb32758aa22c6

commit_message:
Remove stub_network flag

Fixes bug #816025

remove stub_network flag and replace usage with stubbing out of relevant
calls in tests.
In nova/tests/fake_network.py , I add set_stub_network_methods and
unset_stub_network_methods. They can be userd for tests.

Change-Id: Ie8fa95d9ab62cced00f0917cffe75ebc6c94bb3e

(3 inline comments)

Did a review on the new modules, and I've got a couple questions before I go on. In short, I feel like you feel the implementation would be overridden a lot in the future; hence all the tiny methods to manipulate values. I'm not sure the complex class implementations as they stand solve any problem a couple functions in a model wouldn't. At the very least, I think the classes themselves could be simplified. Correct me if I'm wrong.

Sometimes I miss the "needs information" button from Launchpad.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-06 23:08:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-08-09 16:22:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Maybe I'm missing something but I don't see how this addresses the race condition;  all of the claim logic seems to be on the manager side, whereas the race condition occurs when a schduler sees old data beacues a message is in flight to a compute manager.

By contrast the quota code creates a reservation on the api side and passes the reservation down to the compute manager - that seems a much stronger model for a busy system.

I like the contents of what's being reported, and the estimation of I/O operations based on instance state."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-09 16:57:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Phil:  This pushes race condition resolving over to the compute manager, where it is authoritative for its instances.  I feel real reservations in the DB (like we have for quotas) are too heavy of operations and they have the potential of getting out of sync and breaking without an easy way to resolve them.

By allowing compute to have all of the logic to resolve the race conditions, we can use things like semaphore locks... and have periodic tasks that can heal the compute_nodes table to make sure it's in sync.

It solves the race because of this patch (scheduler retries) having been merged previously: 

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9540/

If compute finds that there's not room for the instance it should be building, the request will end up being kicked back to the scheduler to re-try another host."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-09 17:05:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

To add to Chris' explanation, these patches effectively implements optimistic concurrency control for building instances."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-08-09 17:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Chris and Johannes for the clarification.

So I was partly right - I was missing something ;-)
(and I reviewed the scheduer retries patch as well - i need a holiday)'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-09 17:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Brian,

The issue seems to be releated to the free_disk_gb calculations on a new installation. What I'm doing w/ SmokeStack is creating a fresh DB for every single run. When I do that w/ your patch it shows free_disk_gb getting calculated as a negative values (which shouldn't be)

-bash-4.2# nova hypervisor-stats
+----------------------+-------+
|       Property       | Value |
+----------------------+-------+
|        count         |   1   |
|   current_workload   |   0   |
| disk_available_least |   0   |
|     free_disk_gb     |   -5  |
|     free_ram_mb      | 45674 |
|       local_gb       |   16  |
|    local_gb_used     |   21  |
|      memory_mb       | 49139 |
|    memory_mb_used    |  3465 |
|     running_vms      |   0   |
|        vcpus         |   0   |
|      vcpus_used      |   0   |
+----------------------+-------+

----

So... when trying to boot an instance there are essentially no disk resources to be found. This seems to be the root of the failures I am seeing."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-08-20 15:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-08-20 15:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Dan,

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-05 20:34:21.000000000', 'message': "Keep the ComputeNode model updated with usage

Keep the compute host's ComputeNode model in sync with the
level of resource usage.  This enables the ComputeNode
model to be used as a basis for scheduling decisions
rather than forcing scheduler to calculate free
resources from an instance_get_all on each requests.

Resources like memory and disk are claimed as instances are built
or deleted.  There is also support for configurable compute node
stats (a generic key/value store) for extensible advertising of other
usage stats that may be useful for a particular scheduler
implementation.  Additionally, there is a periodic task on the
compute host that audits actual resource consumption at the virt
layer to ensure that the database stays in sync.

This change partially implements blueprint: scheduler-resource-race

(A second patch will be provided soon that retries scheduling
if a compute host is oversubscribed.)

Change-Id: Ibbe3839a054f8b80664b413d47f766ca8d68e3f2

commit_message:
Keep the ComputeNode model updated with usage

Keep the compute host's ComputeNode model in sync with the
level of resource usage.  This enables the ComputeNode
model to be used as a basis for scheduling decisions
rather than forcing scheduler to calculate free
resources from an instance_get_all on each request.

Resources like memory and disk are claimed as instances are built
or deleted.  There is also support for configurable compute node
stats (a generic key/value store) for extensible advertising of other
usage stats that may be useful for a particular scheduler
implementation.  Additionally, there is a periodic task on the
compute host that audits actual resource consumption at the virt
layer to ensure that the database stays in sync.

This change partially implements blueprint: scheduler-resource-race

This patch complements:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9540/  (build re-scheduling support)

Change-Id: Ibbe3839a054f8b80664b413d47f766ca8d68e3f2

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-08-21 02:51:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Vish: Couldn't we do this in the XMLSerializers just as well?

I'm a bit concerned about changing these late in the game I guess. It seems like people may not always tread 'None' and '' the same from a client prospective right?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-21 03:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dan: we were discussing it a lot on irc today. It makes our extensions really hard to use properly if null data is sometimes displayed as "" (disk_config, access_ip_v4) and sometimes as null (extended_status, key_name). Since the core apis all convert nulls to "" I think the extensions should do so as well. I could be convinced to leave the nulls in the json representation for compatiblity reasons, but I think we are going to be in a very ugly place if we do so.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-21 11:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The changes make sense to me - it doesn't appear that '' vs None is a useful distinction for any of these server properties, so I'm not worried about the need to represent both values

But, to be clear, this is an API change and we even explicitly say "Inconsistencies that need breaking changes can be fixed in a new API version" in http://wiki.openstack.org/APIChangeGuidelines

I was about to +2, but then considered e.g. task_state - isn't it conceivable that some existing client polls the task state and waits for it to change to null? There is potential for client breakage here IMHO

I'm thinking this is something should defer until the v3 API'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-21 16:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Abandoning to keep api consistency'}]

Change-Id: Ibc0f6d0f3fbad521e8131e356ff0fa6f3147ebb3
"}]
commit_message:
Fix handling of nulls in servers output extensions

Some of the output extensions were returning null values, which do
not display well in xml. This changes them to convert null values
to ''.

Fixes bug 1039266

Change-Id: Ibc0f6d0f3fbad521e8131e356ff0fa6f3147ebb3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-07 14:24:37.000000000', 'message': 'fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
Cherry-picked: a5184d5dbf67630dac3abb69b1678b60807cfce7
'}, {'created': '2012-08-21 14:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
Cherry-picked: a5184d5dbf67630dac3abb69b1678b60807cfce7
'}]
commit_message:
fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
Cherry-picked: a5184d5dbf67630dac3abb69b1678b60807cfce7

[{'created': '2012-08-15 05:18:41.000000000', 'message': 'Restore libvirt block storage connections on reboot.

Fixes bug 1036902 -- Backported version for stable/essex.

There are a number of cases where block storage connections are not
properly restored, impacting libvirt in particular. The most common
case is a VM which has block storage attached via iSCSI, whereby the
physical system is rebooted. When the system comes back up and
starts nova-compute, the iSCSI connections are NOT recreated for the
instances slated to be resumed (assuming
resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set).

The patch changes the compute manager to pass block_storage_info via
driver.reboot() and driver.resume_state_on_host_boot(). The fix is
actually only present in the libvirt driver. However, all the other
drivers were updated to accept the additional, optional function
arg.

With the changes in place, iSCSI connections for libvirt are
re-established after a hypervisor reboot with
resume_guests_state_on_host_boot=True and on every hard_reboot.
The latter is intended so that users have a last ditch option for
recovering their VMs without administrative involvement.

commit_message:
Restore libvirt block storage connections on reboot.

Fixes bug 1036902 -- Backported version for stable/essex.

There are a number of cases where block storage connections are not
properly restored, impacting libvirt in particular. The most common
case is a VM which has block storage attached via iSCSI, whereby the
physical system is rebooted. When the system comes back up and
starts nova-compute, the iSCSI connections are NOT recreated for the
instances slated to be resumed (assuming
resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set).

The patch changes the compute manager to pass block_storage_info via
driver.reboot() and driver.resume_state_on_host_boot(). The fix is
actually only present in the libvirt driver. However, all the other
drivers were updated to accept the additional, optional function
arg.

With the changes in place, iSCSI connections for libvirt are
re-established after a hypervisor reboot with
resume_guests_state_on_host_boot=True and on every hard_reboot.
The latter is intended so that users have a last ditch option for
recovering their VMs without administrative involvement.

Change-Id: I8ab3a138b559ee0aa1535a928282e9c372ec5651

fix associating a floating IP during floating IP creation.

bug 1038962

also add check to make sure that floating IP's are only associated if
the upstream router has a external network gateway to the appropriate
external network.

Change-Id: Ie4cb632296ce4a1cb989242eb894d73a7488cdb3

just got bitten by this'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-08-15 20:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

zcat --force

is supposed to behave like cat when the input is not compressed.  Where is this failing?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-17 01:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

the glance upload never completes. Try for example in localrc:

IMAGE_URLS="http://launchpad.net/cirros/trunk/0.3.0/+download/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk.img"

You end up with an image stuck in saving:

| 8e998f3f-931e-458f-9446-f617550d1242 | cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk | SAVING |        |

works fine with the fix here.

The man page for zcat --force says:

If the input data is not in a format recognized by gzip, and if the option --stdout is also given, copy the input data without change to the standard output: let zcat behave as cat.

so perhaps it doesn't fallback because we aren't using --stdout ?'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2012-08-17 01:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This happened on Ubuntu 12.04'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-08-17 02:23:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If we can add --stdout I'd prefer that.  I've never seen this problem, I'll try to replicate it tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2012-08-17 04:51:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll try --stdout when I get the chance"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-08-17 14:39:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2012-08-12 03:27:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for glance image-create of *.qcow2 and *.img files

Currently *.qcow2 and *.img files in IMAGE_URLS are piped into glance
using zcat, which fails and leaves the image in a perpetual SAVING state.

This change makes only *.img.gz files use zcat.

Change-Id: I6e02ccff93a42bbc149d8f1058bba7825c910e05
'}]
commit_message:
Fix for glance image-create of *.qcow2 and *.img files

Currently *.qcow2 and *.img files in IMAGE_URLS are piped into glance
using zcat, which fails and leaves the image in a perpetual SAVING state.

This change makes only *.img.gz files use zcat.

Change-Id: I6e02ccff93a42bbc149d8f1058bba7825c910e05

commit_message:
Only allow a single network to be created

Part of os-api-network-create

Change the network create API so that we only allow creating a single
network at a time. This makes the API more RESTful, because when you
POST an network representation you are now guaranteed that only a
single network can be created and return.

Do this by setting num_networks=1 and calculating network_size before
passing the request onto the network manager.

Change-Id: I4acea101bef435ad0cb5082657c026265e1c3cb3

subject: Adding support for multiple volume backends in a single volume-manager.
messages:
[{'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-08-10 22:34:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Need to add Test and make sure it doesn't break any of the other drivers."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-10 22:40:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure I understand the value of having one manager support multiple backends. Why not just have multiple managers and let the scheduler schedule to the right manager by volume_type? This was one of the original purposes of having volume_type.

That seems much cleaner than storing backends in the database.

Vish"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-10 22:43:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-cinder-merge/536/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-cinder-docs/460/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-cinder-pep8/499/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-cinder-python26/493/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-cinder-python27/500/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/7436/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-08-13 15:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmm. I think I might have overlooked volume_types, I agree that could be leveraged for this instead of a new table. I'll look at modifying that.

But I'd still argue against not having support for multiple drivers with the same volume manager. Most of the volume drivers have nothing to do with the local machine they are on, it's some storage backend they are talking to. It makes it really cumbersome for operators that are managing anywhere in the 10's no. of backends to have that many volume-managers running, when all it's doing is talking to a backend. From an operators perspective it might be very beneficial to have this support, also note that this does not eliminate options to still run a single driver, you get to choose thru configuration."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-08-21 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-08-21 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
